title.value: In-Context Learning for Text Classification with Many Labels
title.justification: The title clearly reflects the content and focus of the paper, which is on leveraging in-context learning for text classification tasks involving numerous labels.
title.quote: In-Context Learning for Text Classification with Many Labels

extractions.description: The paper studies in-context learning (ICL) using large language models (LLMs) for tasks with many labels, addressing the challenge posed by the limited context window of these models. It proposes a method to overcome this limitation by using a pre-trained dense retrieval model to provide the model with a partial view of the full label space for each inference call. The method is evaluated on multiple datasets, showing state-of-the-art performance in certain settings without finetuning.

type.justification: The study involves empirical evaluation of methods using experiments on multiple datasets and models to demonstrate performance outcomes.
type.quote: By testing on intent classification (upwards of 50 classes) and fine-grained sentiment analysis (upwards of 25 classes), we demonstrate that the resulting performance with this method can reach SoTA.

name.justification: The paper discusses methods and experiments involving large language models and deep learning techniques.
name.quote: In-context learning (ICL) using large language models (LLMs) has recently exploded in popularity.

name.justification: The study specifically focuses on text classification tasks, which is a key area within NLP.
name.quote: We evaluate LLMs in this setting with three intent classification datasets: BANKING77, HWU64, and CLINC150, as well as one fine-grained sentiment classification dataset: GoEmotions.

name.justification: The paper mentions testing with OPT models to achieve state-of-the-art performance in few-shot settings.
name.quote: Testing with recent open-source LLMs (OPT, LLaMA), we set new state of the art performance in few-shot settings.

name.justification: The paper mentions testing with LLaMA models to achieve state-of-the-art performance in few-shot settings.
name.quote: Testing with recent open-source LLMs (OPT, LLaMA), we set new state of the art performance in few-shot settings.

name.justification: The paper compares the performance of their method with the DeBERTa-v2-XXLarge model.
name.quote: We compare the performance achieved against adapter-based fine-tuning of MLM models (DeBERTa-v2-XXLarge with the 'Pfeiffer' bottleneck-style adapter...).

name.justification: The paper uses a pre-trained SBERT model as a retriever for in-context learning.
name.quote: By coupling the LLM with an external pre-trained dense retriever model (Reimers and Gurevych, 2019a; Karpukhin et al., 2020), we can dynamically retrieve a set of examples to provide to the LM in-context.

name.justification: The paper evaluates its methods using the BANKING77 dataset.
name.quote: We evaluate LLMs in this setting with three intent classification datasets: BANKING77, HWU64, and CLINC150, as well as one fine-grained sentiment classification dataset: GoEmotions.

name.justification: The paper evaluates its methods using the HWU64 dataset.
name.quote: We evaluate LLMs in this setting with three intent classification datasets: BANKING77, HWU64, and CLINC150, as well as one fine-grained sentiment classification dataset: GoEmotions.

name.justification: The paper evaluates its methods using the CLINC150 dataset.
name.quote: We evaluate LLMs in this setting with three intent classification datasets: BANKING77, HWU64, and CLINC150, as well as one fine-grained sentiment classification dataset: GoEmotions.

name.justification: The paper evaluates its methods using the GoEmotions dataset for fine-grained sentiment classification.
name.quote: We evaluate LLMs in this setting with three intent classification datasets: BANKING77, HWU64, and CLINC150, as well as one fine-grained sentiment classification dataset: GoEmotions.

name.justification: AdapterHub is referenced as a tool used for implementing fine-tuning methods in the paper.
name.quote: We compare the performance achieved against adapter-based fine-tuning of MLM models (DeBERTa-v2-XXLarge with the 'Pfeiffer' bottleneck-style adapter (Pfeiffer et al., 2020b) implemented with AdapterHub...

name.justification: The paper uses the SentenceTransformers library for the SBERT retrieval model.
name.quote: For our sentence encoder/retriever, we use the SentenceTransformers library (Reimers and Gurevych, 2019a).

name.justification: The paper compares its method's performance to SetFit, a lightweight method for contrastive training.
name.quote: SetFit (Tunstall et al., 2022) results are also provided, a method involving contrastive fine-tuning of a retriever model with a classification head, as it is also a competitive and lightweight baseline in this setup.
